Award.AwardTitle: Modular Riboswitch Reporters for Directed Protein Evolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes program is supporting the research of Professors Robert Batey and Shelley Copley of the University of Colorado, Boulder. Profs. Batey and Copley will develop a modular and versatile method for creating small molecule biosensors that can be utilized to monitor directed protein evolution. The hypothesis is that one can reverse engineer a form of RNA-based regulation namely "riboswitches" that are found in the leader sequences of mRNAs that directly bind small molecules to direct expression of the message. This proposal aims to exploit these RNAs by two means. First, a "mix-and-match" methodology will be developed that allows a broad array of small molecule receptors to be spliced into biologically efficient regulatory switches that drive in vivo expression of fluorescent protein reporters. Second, in vitro selection methods will be developed to take advantage of the properties of riboswitches to access a new generation of RNA-based small molecule receptors. Finally, these approaches are to be applied to a directed evolution project that selects for variants of homoserine kinase that improve the efficiency of a novel biochemical pathway for synthesis of a critical cofactor.

The Broader Impacts of this project will be to develop new approaches that are widely applicable to synthetic biology. One of the primary goals of this project is to make these techniques easy to apply to a broad spectrum of protein evolution applications by researchers with diverse molecular biology skills. Through this project, graduate and undergraduate students will be exposed to research and coursework at the Chemistry-Biology interface as developed collaboratively by Professors Batey and Copley.

Genetically encodable nucleic acid biosensors that directly sense small molecules are increasingly viewed as important and powerful tools in chemical and synthetic biology. This perspective is driven by two key properties of nucleic acids: the ability to evolve new functional molecules in vitro and the conceptual ease of designing devices using simple secondary structural considerations. A typical biosensor is composed of a small molecule binding receptor (called an "aptamer") that serves as the input domain and an output domain that elicits a readable signal in response to the receptor (Figure 1).

            Despite their promise, practical implementation of RNA-based devices in real-world applications faces significant hurdles; only a few small molecule binding RNA aptamers have transitioned into effective and widely used intracellular biosensors. For example, while aptamers can be raised against nearly any desired target by in vitro selection, many of these RNAs cannot be easily integrated into devices or do not reliably fold or function in a cellular context. The overarching goal of the funded proposal was to develop new approaches enabling the engineering of such devices for applications like directed protein evolution. Over the course of the funded proposal we have made significant advances towards the facile engineering of RNA biosensor through (1) development of modular RNA switches that control expression of an output fluorescent protein reporter and (2) new approaches to evolving bio-inspired RNA aptamers that function as robust small molecule sensor input devices in the cellular context.

            To achieve our first research goal, we investigated a series of naturally occurring mRNA-based regulatory elements found in bacteria called "riboswitches" that regulate protein expression in response to a specific cellular metabolites. In response to a small molecule binding to the aptamer domain (receptor), a secondary structural switch adopts one of two potential conformations: one that causes RNA polymerase to abort synthesis of the mRNA transcript and a second that enable the message to be fully synthesized and its encoded protein to be expressed. Based upon our analysis of several natural riboswitches, we hypothesized that some of these natural switches could be engineered to be "composable"—that is, able to interface with different aptamers. We developed two modular "ON" switches that are capable of hosting a spectrum of aptamer domains, synthetic and natural, and turn on expression of a fluorescent protein in response to the aptamer's cognate small molecule (Figure 2a). These devices function robustly both in vitro and in the cellular environment in response to their cognate ligand (Figure 2b). Importantly, the "rules" to engineer and optimize newly created RNA biosensors is based almost exclusively on simple secondary structural considerations. This research represents the first composable and modular RNA switches, an important step towards facile construction of RNA biosensors for use in bacterial cells.
